title: How to use (and build on) mevolCVP2
text: tiny package (finally) releases seminal idea coined Allowen Evin colleagues Journal Archaeological Science 2013. approach previously available single script (circa 2013), wrapped package (circa 2018) without change code released CRAN. Evin et al. (2013) paper, among others, used “predictive” discriminant analyses morphometrical analyses, particularly context landmark-based morphometrics uses principal component analyses prior LDA. idea two-fold: ) parameterized optimal number principal components retain linear discriminant analyses, ii) evaluated effects unbalanced sample sized groups LDA. Yet approach deeply changed way see, parameterize LDAs morphometrics, actualy boils , statistically, following two core ideas.

Along last ~10 years (2014->2024), thus systematically investigated number components (harmonics) retain used permutations obtain balanced datasets. side effect, use permutationnal approaches typically allows obtain true distribution H0H_0, words compare model performances pure random. morphometrical studies, allowed detect subtle yet significant morphological signals even relatively low accuracies. words, even model 60% accuracy (far impressive) may better random (ie binomial coin) thus reveal true morphological signal.

title: Balance a data.frame — balance
text: Balance `n` individuals group, taken first column

title: Balance a data.frame — balance
text: x data.frame first column grouping column n integer number individuals group. Smallest sample size default.

title: Balance a data.frame — balance
text: balanced data.frame

title: Balance a data.frame — balance
text: Note [sample]() done `replace=TRUE`

title: Balance a data.frame — balance
code: # untouched dataset is not balanced table(pig$sp) #>  #>  DP  WB  #>  42 129  # balance helps table(balance(pig)$sp) #>  #> DP WB  #> 42 42

title: Linear discricriminant analysis — lda1

title: Linear discricriminant analysis — lda1
code: pig %>% lda1() #>       predicted #> actual  DP  WB #>     DP  31  11 #>     WB   6 123

title: Randomize a data.frame — randomize
text: Randomize data.frame shuffling first column

title: Randomize a data.frame — randomize
text: x data.frame first column grouping column

title: Randomize a data.frame — randomize
text: shuffled data.frame

title: Randomize a data.frame — randomize
code: # untouched dataset head(pig$sp, 10) #>  [1] WB WB WB WB WB WB WB WB WB WB #> Levels: DP WB # balance helps head(randomize(pig)$sp, 10) #>  [1] WB DP WB WB WB DP WB WB WB WB #> Levels: DP WB

what: Retain some variables from a data.frame — retain
title: Retain some variables from a data.frame — retain
text: Retain `n` columns, first let apart.

title: Retain some variables from a data.frame — retain
Retain some variables from a data.frame — retain
text: x data.frame first column grouping column n integer number columns retain. default.

title: Retain some variables from a data.frame — retain
text: data.frame

title: Retain some variables from a data.frame — retain
code: # untouched dataset with all its columns ncol(pig) #> [1] 51 # after retaining only 12 (plus the 1st as the grouping) ncol(retain(pig, 12)) #> [1] 13
